column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: In March 2023, we published our first standalone TCFD Statement for 12 months to 30 June 2022. The report highlights Vicinity's work on climate to date, including completing a climate scenario analysis of key transition risks and opportunities and reviewing our Net Zero Target against the Paris Agreement.\t

column6: Defined benefit plan obligations and other retirement plans
Ratios of standard entry level wage by gender compared to local minimum wage
Proportion of senior management hired from the local community

column13: Our centres support, promote and participate in local events, make financial contributions, provide in-kind goods, services and mall space for fundraising, and leverage consumers and retailers to make community initiatives more successful.
column20: Community Engagement, Corporate Sponsorship, Local Impact

column13: Our bespoke consumer research platform, Vicinity Voice, has successfully delivered more than 30 consumer research projects since its launch in 2022, benefitting a cross-section of teams across the organisation. Vicinity Voice enables us to expand the reach of our research cost-effectively, allowing us to conduct more and more frequent research. It reduces the requirement to engage external service providers.
column20: Market Research, Consumer Insights, Stakeholder Engagement

column13: In our third RAP, we have further committed to deepening relationships, increasing cultural awareness, and connecting Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples with employment and business opportunities across our organisation. In FY23, Vicinity's Indigenous procurement spend was $5.4 million, exceeding the target set in our roadmap.

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
column13: We take a proactive approach to managing sustainability risks inherent in our supply chain. We also recognise unique opportunities to create value through our relationships with suppliers.
column20: Supply Chain Management, Risk Mitigation, Sustainable Practices

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column7: We provide regular training to ensure our people know these policies and their obligations. All employees are required to complete training within 12 weeks of employment and annually after that.

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices

column13: To improve the transparency of business tax affairs in Australia, the Board of Taxation designed the Tax Transparency Code (TTC) to outline principles and minimum standards to guide the disclosure of tax information. Vicinity adopts the TTC recommendations in this statement.
column20: Tax Transparency, Financial Disclosure, Regulatory Compliance

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: Vicinity has a Tax Risk Management Framework (the Framework) that the Audit Committee endorses. Vicinity adheres to the principles of the Framework, which affirms our low-risk approach to taxation and a philosophy centred around integrity and transparency.
column20: Tax Risk Management, Governance Structure, Compliance

column6: Tax governance, control, and risk management
column13: Has robust tax governance, with ongoing oversight and escalation points for managing tax risk from Vicinity's key executives to the Audit Committee and Board of Directors; commits to engaging and maintaining transparent and professional relationships with tax authorities, including the Australian Taxation Office (ATO)

column6: Stakeholder engagement and management of concerns related to tax
column13: Vicinity values having good relationships with all stakeholders. We engage and consult with external regulatory bodies regarding tax policy, tax reform and tax law design on matters relevant to our business and our securityholders. Vicinity also regularly connects with and encourages feedback from its securityholders.
column20: Stakeholder Engagement, Relationship Management, Corporate Reputation

column6: Materials used by weight or volume
Reclaimed products and thei packaging materials

column13: In conjunction with the BMS upgrade, an Automated Demand Response (ADR) function has been implemented to provide visibility and control over the energy consumption of standard area services by installing live meters. The ADR's demand response capabilities help manage peak demand, reducing the reliance on non-renewable energy during high-load periods.\t
column20: Energy Management, Demand Response, Sustainability Initiatives

column13: In FY19, we committed to a $73 million investment in onsite solar generation to deliver energy resilience and efficiencies and ultimately assist us in meeting our Net Zero Target. Since the first solar panels were installed at Castle Plaza, SA, in December 2018, we have installed 33.49 MW worth of solar capacity across 22 centres. It includes Chadstone, VIC's additional solar as part of The Social Quarter and Chadstone Place developments during FY23.\t
column20: Solar Investment, Energy Resilience, Net Zero Target

column6: Energy consumption outside of the organization

column13: Energy efficiency is a critical component of our broader resource efficiency program that focuses on driving continuous improvements in how we manage energy, water and materials across the operations of our assets. Our portfolio and centre-level targets and initiatives support the program, including a lifecycle replacement program focusing on lighting, vertical transport, heating and cooling, and optimising building operations and performance through building management systems.
column20: Energy Efficiency, Resource Management, Lifecycle Replacement

column13: In FY23, we commenced a centralised Building Management System (BMS) solution across Vicinity's portfolio on the Azure cloud to enable centralised remote management of building operations for both centre and head office teams. When the rollout is complete, this will deliver a consistent and uniform system across all centres, improving efficiency and providing cost savings. This upgrade will allow our centres to develop data-driven strategies to optimise energy consumption, leading to reduced electricity usage and lower carbon emissions.
column20: Building Management System, Remote Management, Cost Savings

column13: Working closely with our operations teams, we have implemented best practice initiatives across several Green Star categories, including management, indoor air quality, energy, water, materials, emissions and innovation. Our asset portfolio is one of Australia's largest and highest-rated Green Star Performance retail portfolios, achieving a 4-Star Green Star Performance portfolio rating in FY19.

column6: Reductions in energy requirements of products and services
Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: Water use intensity increased by 14% in FY23 from FY22, reflecting a return to a full year of normal operations following COVID-19 restrictions in FY22. However, proactive water use management has reduced water use intensity by 9% since the FY16 baseline. Absolute water use has remained stable, up only 2%, despite a 12% increase in GLA.
column20: Water Management, Proactive Approach, NABERS Benchmarking

column6: Interactions with water as a shared resource
column13: NABERS provides a specific and accurate framework to measure retail assets' energy and water efficiency. Vicinity uses the NABERS shopping centre tool to assess and benchmark the performance of its buildings.
column20: NABERS Rating, Energy and Water Efficiency, Benchmarking Tool

column7: To reduce water use, we are progressively installing water submetering across the portfolio for water-intensive tenants such as car washes and food retailers and at primary base-building uses such as irrigation and amenities.
